The GM might decide that other types of damage are applicable in rarer environments.
Drawback You aren't immune to the chaos of your power. You must be included in the aura of this psyche and must save against it as normal.

feat.name: Cranial Detonation
entries: As your magic fells a creature, you take advantage of their flickering consciousness to release a detonation of psychic energy from the creature's head. Use this amp in place of the psi cantrip's normal amp entry. Unlike with many amps, you choose to add this amp to a spell after you've successfully reduced a non‑mindless enemy to 0 Hit Points with the spell, rather than as part of Casting the Spell. You can't use this amp on a nonlethal spell.

Amp The enemy you reduced to 0 Hit Points dies (a {@trait death} effect), and its head explodes. If the cantrip reduced more than one foe to 0 Hit Points, choose one head to detonate. The detonation generates a shockwave in a 15‑foot emanation around that enemy. Each creature in the emanation takes {@dice 1d4} damage per level of the amped spell, with a basic save against your spell DC. You choose a physical or mental shockwave, and the explosion deals force damage with a basic Fortitude save (for a physical shockwave) or mental damage with a basic Will save (for a mental shockwave).

feat.name: Deepest Wellspring
entries: You've traveled to the furthest depths of your subconscious, granting you even more focus. Increase the number of Focus Points in your focus pool by 1. If you've spent at least 3 Focus Points since the last time you {@action Refocus||Refocused}, you recover 3 Focus Points when you {@action Refocus} instead of 1.

feat.name: Become Thought
entries: You shed some of your material form, becoming a being of pure thought. You gain resistance 10 to physical damage but weakness 5 to mental damage and weakness 10 to any effect that deals damage specifically by targeting the spirit, such as spirit blast. Once per century, when you die, you automatically return to life as long as one living sentient creature on your plane remembers you; the memories allow you to reconstruct yourself from their thoughts.

feat.name: Dual Amplification
entries: You can modify and amplify your spells as much as you like.
You can apply two amps to a focus cantrip, instead of one, provided those amps can both be applied to the spell. It costs only 1 Focus Point to add both amps.

feat.name: Mind Over Matter
entries: Your mind's limits are only what you imagine them to be. You gain an additional 10th‑level spell slot.

feat.name: Multifaceted Psyche
feat.requirements: You have at least two psyche abilities.
entries: You've uncovered so many facets of your psyche that you can bring two to the front when your mind is unleashed. If you've met the requirements for two psyche abilities, when you Unleash your psyche, you can enter both simultaneously, gaining both benefits and both drawbacks.

feat.name: Binding Oath
entries: You bind yourself by speaking an oath. Supernatural power flows through and around you as you speak it, and all those present to hear it intrinsically know that it binds you, preventing you from willingly acting against your declared oath or ignoring promises made as part of the oath. Thaumaturges use this ability to earn trust from others and lend weight to their promises, allowing them to more easily offer an oath or promise as part of a bargain. The oath doesn't prevent unwilling violations and can't be used to try to circumvent mind-control magic, confusion, or similar situations where you perform an action not entirely of your own volition. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to {@action Request} or {@action Coerce} creatures aware of your oath if you invoke it as part of a promise you make, due to the fact that the creatures know you must try to keep that promise.

If you have expert proficiency in {@skill Arcana}, {@skill Nature}, {@skill Occultism}, or {@skill Religion}, you can swear a binding oath two times per day; if you have master proficiency in one of these skills, three times; and if you have legendary proficiency, as many times as you like.

feat.name: Divine Disharmony
entries: You pull out multiple opposing divine objects—such as the religious symbols of two deities that are hated enemies—and combine them in a display that is not only galling, but also causes discordant clashes of divine energy that are especially distracting to the faithful. Roll your choice of a {@skill Deception} or {@skill Intimidation} check against the Will DC of a creature you can see within 60 feet, with the following results. If the creature is particularly devoted to a deity, such as a cleric, celestial, monitor, fiend, or other creature with divine spells, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus to your skill check. The GM might determine that a creature that despises all deities, such as an alghollthu, is unaffected.

entries.Critical Success: The creature is {@condition flat-footed} to your attacks until the end of your next turn.
entries.Success: The creature is {@condition flat-footed} against your attacks until the end of your current turn.

feat.name: Esoteric Lore
entries: Your diverse studies into various sources of lore mean you've heard rumors or theories about almost every topic... though admittedly, your sources aren't always the most reliable. You are trained in {@skill Lore||Esoteric Lore}, a special {@skill Lore} skill that can be used only to {@action Recall Knowledge}, but on any topic.

If you have legendary proficiency in {@skill Arcana}, {@skill Nature}, {@skill Occultism}, or {@skill Religion}, you gain expert proficiency in {@skill Lore||Esoteric Lore}, but you can't increase your proficiency rank in {@skill Lore||Esoteric Lore} by any other means.

feat.name: Familiar
entries: Whether by following occult rituals, piecing together scraps of arcane theory, or some other method, you've called forth a creature that now serves as your constant companion in your studies of the supernatural. You gain a familiar.

feat.name: Haunt Cunning
entries: One of the most useful pieces of cunning knowledge is the ability to notice the emotional echo of a soul that passed on, leaving a haunt in its wake. Even when you aren't Searching while in exploration mode, the GM rolls a secret check for you to notice haunts that usually require you to be Searching.

You can disable haunts that require master proficiency rank in a skill as long as you're at least trained in the skill. If you have master proficiency in the skill, you can disable haunts that require a proficiency rank of legendary instead.

While holding a lantern implement, you also gain a +1 circumstance bonus to {@skill Perception} checks to find haunts, to AC against attacks made by haunts, and to saves against haunts. If you have the lantern implement's adept benefit, the circumstance bonus is +2.

feat.name: Root To Life
entries: Marigold, spider lily, pennyroyal—many primal traditions connect flowers and plants with the boundary between life and death, and you can leverage this connection to keep an ally on this side of the line. You place a small plant or similar symbol on an adjacent {@condition dying} creature, immediately stabilizing them; the creature is no longer {@condition dying} and is instead {@condition unconscious} at 0 Hit Points.

If you spend 2 actions instead of 1, you empower the act further by uttering a quick folk blessing to chase away ongoing pain, adding the {@trait auditory} trait to the action. When you do so, attempt flat checks to remove each source of {@condition persistent damage} affecting the target; due to the particularly effective assistance, the DC is 10 instead of the usual 15.

feat.name: Scroll Thaumaturgy
entries: Your multidisciplinary study of magic means you know how to activate the magic in scrolls with ease. You can Activate scrolls of any magical tradition, using your thaumaturge class DC for the scroll's DC, rather than a particular spell DC.
If a spell is on the spell list for multiple traditions, you choose which tradition to use at the time you Activate the scroll.

feat.name: Call Implement
entries: You can tug on the connections between yourself and your implement, causing it to find its way back to you. You look down at your hand and find your implement has mysteriously appeared in it, as long as it was within 1 mile and on the same plane of existence. If your implement is attended by another creature, that creature can prevent the implement from teleporting away if it succeeds at a Will save against your class DC. If the creature succeeds, you can't attempt to Call that Implement again; you have to track the creature down to get the implement back.

feat.name: Enhanced Familiar
entries: By applying the best of multiple traditions of magic, you've found a more efficient way for your familiar to store its energy. You can select four familiar or master abilities each day, instead of two.

feat.name: Esoteric Warden
entries: When you apply antithetical material against a creature successfully, you also ward yourself against its next attacks.

When you Find Flaws and succeed at your {@action Recall Knowledge} check, in addition to the normal effects, you gain a +1 status bonus to your AC against the creature's next attack and a +1 status bonus to your next saving throw against the creature. These bonuses increase to +2 on a critical success.
You can gain these bonuses only once per day against a particular creature.

feat.name: Talisman Esoterica
entries: You know how to assemble the supernatural objects in your esoterica into a number of temporary talismans. Each day during your daily preparations, you can make two talismans with an item level no higher than half your level. You must know each talisman's formula. A talisman created this way is a temporary item and loses its magic the next time you make your daily preparations.

You know the formulas for all common talismans in the Core Rulebook of your level or lower. You remember your talisman formulas through oral tradition or mnemonics, so you don't need a formula book for them.

feat.name: Draw Warding Circle
feat.requirements: You're benefiting from Esoteric Antithesis.
entries: The circle is the simplest way to define a closed space, and by drawing a circle out of materials that resonate with a given creature, you define a space that prevents its entry—or escape.

You spend 1 minute constructing a circle along the edges of a 10-foot burst, using materials you identified in the process of figuring out the creature's weaknesses, such as salt to keep out a ghost or anointed silver to contain a devil. Anyone except the chosen creature can cross the circle without trouble, but the chosen creature must attempt a Will save against your class DC whenever it attempts to do so. On a failure, the chosen creature remains on the same side of the circle and the action it was using to attempt to cross the circle is disrupted.
Creatures other than the chosen creature can spend a total of three {@action Interact} actions scuffing the circle to break the effect early. These actions don't need to be consecutive.

Because of the amount of time it takes, typically you construct a circle in advance after Investigating a specific creature. A circle remains effective until you either Draw another Warding Circle or your Esoteric Antithesis ends (typically until you use Find Flaws on another creature).

feat.name: Pact Of Fey Glamour
entries: You've sworn a pact with fey powers, granting you the otherworldly appearance of your dreams in exchange for oaths of hospitality. As long as you keep your end of the bargain, your base appearance changes indefinitely to any one appearance you wish that is within the bounds of possibility for your ancestry; this effect can't be counteracted or removed except by violating the pact. Additionally, you can cast {@spell illusory disguise} as a primal innate spell once per day, using your thaumaturge class DC instead of your spell DC if you prefer.

In exchange, you promise to accept any fey's request for hospitality, granting them food, drink, and lodging for up to 3 days and 3 nights. You also promise not to harm any creature to whom you've offered hospitality or who has shown hospitality to you, whether or not that creature is fey, unless that creature does harm first. Refusing hospitality to a fey or violating hospitality causes you to lose the benefits of this feat until you atone for your transgressions, instantly reverting your appearance to the one you had before the pact.

feat.name: One More Activation
entries: You've forged a deeper connection to your invested items, allowing you to activate them more than usual. Once each day, you can {@action Activate an Item} you've invested even after you've used that activation the maximum number of times for its frequency. You can do so only if the item's level is half your level or lower, has a frequency of once per day or more, and you haven't already used the activation this round.

feat.name: Thaumaturgic Ritualist
entries: Your studies into the supernatural have resulted in an especially strong knowledge of rituals. You gain a +2 circumstance bonus to all primary checks to perform a ritual.

You learn two uncommon rituals with a level no higher than half your level; you must meet all prerequisites for casting the ritual to choose it. At 8th level and every 4 levels thereafter, you learn another uncommon ritual with a level no higher than half your level and for which you meet the prerequisites.
You can cast these as the primary caster, but you can't teach them to anyone else or allow someone else to serve as primary caster unless they know the ritual as well.

feat.name: Turn Away Misfortune
feat.trigger: You would attempt a roll affected by a {@trait misfortune} effect.
entries: You perform a superstition, such as casting salt over your shoulder to ward off bad luck. Turn Away Misfortune's {@trait fortune} trait cancels out the {@trait misfortune} effect, causing you to roll normally.

feat.name: Handy Esoterica
entries: You include just about anything you might need amid all your esoterica. You gain the Prescient Planner and Prescient Consumable feats. When using Prescient Planner, you can pull out the item as a 2-action activity to remove your backpack (or a similar container) and draw the item, rather than taking 1 minute.

feat.name: Scroll Esoterica
entries: Your esoterica collection includes scraps of scriptures, magic tomes, druidic markings, and the like, which you can use to create temporary scrolls. Each day during your daily preparations, you can create a single temporary scroll containing a 1st-level spell of any tradition. The spell must be common, or you must otherwise have access to it. This scroll is an unstable, temporary item and loses its magic the next time you make your daily preparations if you haven't used it.
It can't be used to Learn the Spell.
At 8th level, add a second temporary scroll containing a 2nd-level spell.

feat.name: Rule Of Three
feat.requirements: You're benefiting from Esoteric Antithesis, you can see the subject, and you haven't used Find Flaws this round.
entries: You've learned that there is great value in repetition, especially in sets of three. You must be able to speak your intent to the world and call out to the subject of your Esoteric Antithesis, but the subject doesn't need to understand or even hear you for your Rule of Three to take effect. The benefits depend on how many times you've uttered the Rule of Three and last as long as the creature is subject to your Esoteric Antithesis.

items: {@bold First Utterance} No benefit. If you've used Find Flaws in the presence of the creature, that counts as the first utterance (but not if you Found Flaws while Investigating the creature).
{@bold Second Utterance} You gain a +1 status bonus to attack rolls against the creature.
{@bold Third Utterance} The status bonus to attack rolls against the creature increases to +2, and the creature becomes flatfooted against your attacks.

feat.name: Elaborate Talisman Esoterica
entries: As you continue to collect talismanic esoterica, you improve your ability to create temporary talismans. You can create four temporary talismans each day instead of two.

feat.name: Incredible Familiar
entries: Multidisciplinary magical theory grants your familiar even more magic than other familiars. You can select a base of six familiar or master abilities each day, instead of four.

feat.name: Know-it-all
entries: When you've heard of something at all, you've heard about it at length. When you succeed at a Knowledge check, you gain additional information or context. When you critically succeed at a Knowledge check, at the GM's discretion, you might gain even more additional information or context than normal.

feat.name: Pact Of Infernal Prowess
entries: You've sworn a pact with devils, granting you success in life in exchange for your soul in the afterlife. Once per day, when you critically fail a check, you can reroll the check as a free action; this is a {@trait fortune} effect. Additionally, you can choose to automatically succeed at checks to {@action Earn Income} for tasks below your level, without rolling.

However, when you die, your soul is consigned to Hell. You can't be returned to life except by powerful magic such as miracle, and even then, the devils responsible for the contract can track your every move for 1 year. The devils gain the effects of a {@spell discern location} spell. They can also use 10th-level {@spell scrying} on you at will, and you automatically critically fail your saving throw.
special: You can't retrain out of a Pact of Infernal Prowess without journeying to Hell and destroying the devil's written contract spelling out the terms of your pact.

feat.name: Sympathetic Weakness
entries: You've learned how to expand your invocation of esoterica to apply not just to a specific individual, but other creatures with similar weaknesses, bringing you greater power. While you benefit from Esoteric Antithesis, your Strikes also count towards the weakness of any other creature with the same weakness your Esoteric Antithesis is set to. For instance, if you used Esoteric Antithesis on a red dragon, revealing its weakness 20 to cold and causing your Strikes to deal additional damage, you would also deal additional damage to the dragon's fire elemental minions, which have weakness 10 to cold. No other effects of Esoteric Antithesis apply to other creatures with the same weakness, and this feat has no effect when you create a custom weakness in a creature that otherwise has none.

feat.name: Share Antithesis
feat.requirements: Your Esoteric Antithesis is set to a weakness its subject has (not a custom weakness).
entries: You apply esoterica to an adjacent ally's weapons and body.
That ally's Strikes apply the weakness of the subject of your esoterica the same way your Strikes do. This benefit ends when Esoteric Antithesis ends or you Share Antithesis again.
You can't share a custom weakness you created with Esoteric Antithesis, only a weakness the creature has normally.

feat.name: Thaumaturge's Investiture
entries: Using your knowledge of esoterica and implements, you can invest far more items than most. You gain the {@feat Incredible Investiture} skill feat, increasing your limit on invested items from 10 to 12. The limit increases to 14 if you have Charisma 18, 16 if you have Charisma 20, 18 if you have Charisma 22, and 20 if you have Charisma 24.

feat.name: Twin Weakness
feat.requirements: You're holding an implement and a weapon, and the subject of your Esoteric Antithesis is within reach of both.
entries: As you make an attack augmented by your esoterica, you also press your implement against the creature to apply its weakness. Make a melee {@action Strike} against the subject of your Esoteric Antithesis. On any attack roll result but a critical failure, you also press your implement against the creature, applying its weakness from Esoteric Antithesis.
This is in addition to any damage from your {@action Strike}, including the weakness it applies. This counts as two attacks when calculating your multiple attack penalty.

feat.name: Elaborate Scroll Esoterica
entries: Your connection to your scroll esoterica grows stronger, allowing you to create much more powerful scrolls. In addition to your daily scrolls from Scroll Esoterica, add a scroll with a 3rd-level spell. At 14th level, add a scroll with a 4th-level spell.
At 16th level, add a scroll with a 5th-level spell.

feat.name: Pact Of The Final Breath
entries: You've sworn a pact with powerful psychopomps—typically an olethros advocate or yamaraj judge—granting you a reprieve before your soul will be collected, in exchange for respect for the dead and assistance against the undead. As long as you keep your end of the bargain, you live twice as long as you normally would before {@condition dying} of natural causes. Additionally, the first time each day that you would be reduced to 0 Hit Points and gain the {@condition dying} condition, you instead regain a number of Hit Points equal to your level (starting from 0 HP), remain conscious, and gain fast healing equal to half your level for 3 rounds.

In exchange, you swear to treat the dead you come across with respect, performing last rites and final dispositions to ensure their spirits rest in peace and are less likely to rise as undead. Furthermore, you swear to destroy undead you come across, so long as it's within your power to do so without inordinate risk to yourself. Violating your part of the pact causes its protections to immediately end. If at that point you had already lived beyond your natural life span, the psychopomps typically give you a few moments to make any last farewells, and then you simply breathe your final breath and pass on.

feat.name: Quick Circle
entries: Long hours of practice and an instinctive understanding of boundaries lets you create protective circles impossibly quickly. As you fling your esoterica during a quick spin, you find that everything falls in a perfect circle each time. You can Draw a Warding Circle as a three-action activity, instead of taking 1 minute to do so.

feat.name: Thaumaturge's Demesne
entries: You have claimed an area or location as your demesne, granting you the ability to ward and protect it. When you select this feat, choose a demesne, an area of no more than 200 square feet. You must legitimately claim the area; in the case of a building or property, you must own it, and in the case of an unowned plot of land, no other inhabitants can contest your claim.

Once you've chosen your demesne, it becomes automatically protected with an arcane {@spell private sanctum} spell with an unlimited duration, heightened to half your level rounded up and using your thaumaturge class DC in place of a spell DC, if necessary. Additionally, the demesne is attended by three unseen custodians, as called by a successful unseen custodian ritual (Advanced Player's Guide 245), and one object in the area gains an elemental sentinel, as a successful elemental sentinel ritual (Secrets of Magic 150).

feat.name: Esoteric Reflexes
feat.prerequisites: an implement that grants a reaction
entries: Your connection to your implements is so strong that you can use their reactive abilities almost by instinct. At the start of your turn, you gain an additional reaction, which you can use only for the reactions granted by your implements.

feat.name: Grand Talisman Esoterica
entries: You have completed your journey in studying esoteric talismans, gaining yet more temporary talismans each day.
You can create six temporary talismans each day instead of four.

feat.name: Shared Warding
entries: You ward your allies from the attacks of your foes whenever you apply those protections to yourself. When you gain a status bonus to AC and saves from Esoteric Warden, you can also choose to grant the same benefit to all allies within 30 feet.

feat.name: Implausible Esoterica
entries: It seems impossible, but your esoterica are so eclectic and complete that you can keep pulling out exactly the item you need, even in far-flung locations. You can use Prescient Planner even if you've already used it after purchasing goods, and you can use it as a single action instead of a 2-action activity, during which you {@action Interact} to draw the item.
In addition, five times per day, you can use Prescient Planner to pull out a common consumable item of a level up to 6 levels lower than your level.

feat.name: Implement's Flight
entries: By weakening your connection to the ground and strengthening your connection to the sky, you've learned to soar through the air, your implement carrying you as surely as any broomstick or pestle. As long as you're holding your implement, you gain a fly Speed equal to your land Speed.

feat.name: Sever Magic
feat.requirements: You're holding an implement in one hand.
entries: You apply a frayed thread, a pinch of fulu ash, or a similar undone charm, and you swing to break a spell. Make a {@action Strike} against an enemy. If you hit and deal damage, you attempt to counteract a single spell active on the target (your choice)
Your counteract level is equal to half your level (rounded up), and your counteract check modifier is equal to your class.

feat.name: Trespass Teleportation
feat.trigger: The subject of your Esoteric Antithesis uses a {@trait teleportation} effect and is within 120 feet.
feat.requirements: You're benefiting from Esoteric Antithesis.
entries: Your mystical connection to your foe is so strong that you can follow them to the ends of this world, or any other. You teleport along with the foe, appearing the same direction and distance from it as you were before it teleported away (or the nearest unoccupied space if your destination is occupied).

feat.name: Grand Scroll Esoterica
entries: You've completed the third and final step in your assimilation of scroll esoterica, granting you daily scrolls of incredible power. In addition to your daily scrolls from Scroll Esoterica and Elaborate Scroll Esoterica, add a single scroll with a 6th-level spell. At 20th level, add a scroll with a 7th-level spell.

feat.name: Implement's Assault
feat.requirements: You're holding both an implement and a weapon.
entries: You use your implement to gather physical magic and channel it into your weapon, empowering it to shoot an impossible volley of missiles or soar across the battlefield and carve through your foes. Make a {@action Strike} with your weapon against each foe within 30 feet of you. Don't increase your multiple attack penalty until after making all the attacks. If your weapon is a melee weapon and any of the attacks are outside your reach, you {@action Release} the weapon before the Strikes, and it returns to your grasp after all of them. If your hands are full when the weapon returns, it falls to the ground in your space. As normal, if your weapon requires one or more actions to reload between Strikes, you can't use it to make multiple attacks with Implement's Assault.

feat.name: Intense Implement
entries: You have an exceptional connection to one of your lesser implements, allowing you to tap into more of its power. You gain the adept benefit for one of your implements for which you have only the initiate benefit.

feat.name: Ubiquitous Antithesis
entries: You've channeled your power into the connections you've formed with your comrades, allowing you to share the benefits of your esoterica with all of them. Whenever you use Esoteric Antithesis, all your allies within 30 feet gain the benefits as well. Since this effect depends on magically strengthening your connection to your allies, only allies with whom you've developed a connection over the course of one or more days gain the benefit, rather than new allies you just met.

feat.name: Unlimited Demesne
entries: You can move your demesne from place to place, bringing it along wherever your journey takes you. Once per day, you can invoke your demesne and call it forth, in a process that takes 1 minute. This has the effects of resplendent mansion, except that it conjures forth your demesne from its previous location, with all the benefits of Thaumaturge's Demesne in addition to the benefits of the spell. You must be able to claim the new area as your demesne, with the same restrictions as Thaumaturge's Demesne.

feat.name: Wonder Worker
feat.prerequisites: legendary in {@skill Arcana}, {@skill Nature}, {@skill Occultism}, or {@skill Religion}
entries: You've transcended to the culmination of the thaumaturge's path, gaining the ability to work wonders. Once per day, you can call upon your power to cast a spell of 8th level or lower that takes 1, 2, or 3 actions to cast. The spell must be common or one to which you have access. You can choose a spell of any tradition for which you're legendary in the associated skill ({@skill Arcana} for arcane, {@skill Nature} for primal, {@skill Occultism} for occult, or {@skill Religion} for divine). Use your thaumaturge class DC in place of any necessary spell DC and your thaumaturge class DC – 10 in place of any necessary counteract modifier or spell attack modifier.

feat.name: Arcane Fists
entries: You value physical perfection as much as mental. The damage die for your fist changes to {@dice 1d6} instead of {@dice 1d4}. Most people take a –2 circumstance penalty when making a lethal attack with nonlethal unarmed attacks because they find it hard to use their fists with deadly force. You don't take this penalty when making a lethal attack with your fist or any other unarmed attacks.
You also gain the critical specialization effects of unarmed attacks in the {@group brawling} group and weapons in the {@group brawling} group.

feat.name: Combat Assessment
entries: You make a telegraphed attack to learn about your foe. Make a melee {@action Strike|CRB}. On a hit, you can immediately attempt a check to {@action Recall Knowledge|CRB} about the target. On a critical hit, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus to the check to {@action Recall Knowledge|CRB}. The target is temporarily immune to Combat Assessment for 1 day.

feat.name: Eschew Materials
entries: You can use clever workarounds to replicate the arcane essence of certain materials. When {@action Cast a Spell|CRB|Casting a Spell} that requires material components, you can provide these material components without a spell component pouch by drawing intricate replacement sigils in the air. Unlike when providing somatic components, you still must have a hand completely free. This ability doesn't remove the need for any materials listed in the spell's cost entry.

feat.name: Familiar
entries: You make a pact with creature that serves you and assists your spellcasting. You gain a {@filter familiar|companionsfamiliars||Type=Familiar} (Core Rulebook 217).

feat.name: Raise A Tome
feat.requirements: You're holding a book.
entries: You raise up the book you're holding and flip it open to defend yourself and expedite your studies. The book remains raised until the start of your next turn. While you have a book raised, you gain a +1 circumstance bonus to AC and to {@action Recall Knowledge|CRB} on a subject relevant to the book (such as arcane magic if you're using your spellbook)
If you're a master in the skill you're using to {@action Recall Knowledge|CRB}, the circumstance bonus to the {@action Recall Knowledge|CRB} check is +2 instead.

feat.name: Cantrip Expansion
entries: Dedicated study allows you to prepare a wider range of simple spells. You can prepare two additional cantrips each day.

feat.name: Enhanced Familiar
entries: You infuse your familiar with additional magical energy. You can select four familiar or master abilities each day, instead of two.

feat.name: Spirit Sheath
entries: You've magically constructed an extradimensional sheath for your weapon, typically accessed through a pocket, sleeve, or clothing seam. This sheath is hard to notice, granting a +2 circumstance bonus to your {@skill Stealth} checks to Conceal an Item within it. A spirit sheath can hold only one weapon at a time, and the weapon must be 1 Bulk or less.

You can draw or return a weapon in a spirit sheath as an {@action Interact|CRB} action, as can anyone else holding the object bearing the sheath. When you {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} affected by Striking Spell, you can draw the weapon from your spirit sheath into your hand or hands as part of the {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} activity, storing your spell within the weapon.

feat.name: Bespell Strikes
feat.requirements: Your most recent action was to cast a non‑cantrip spell.
entries: You siphon spell energy into one weapon you're wielding. Until the end of your turn, the weapon deals an extra {@dice 1d6} damage of a type depending on the school of the spell you just cast. You can choose to put the spell energy into your body instead of a weapon, conferring the damage on your unarmed attacks.

items: {@bold Abjuration} force damage
{@bold Conjuration or Transmutation} same type as the weapon
{@bold Divination, Enchantment, or Illusion} mental damage
{@bold Evocation} a type the spell dealt, or force damage if the spell didn't deal damage
{@bold Necromancy} negative damage

feat.name: Spell Parry
feat.requirements: You're wielding only a single one-handed melee weapon and have your other hand or hands free.
entries: You can parry both physical and magical assaults. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to AC and to saving throws against spells that target you until the start of your next turn as long as you continue to meet the requirements.

feat.name: Steady Spellcasting
entries: Confident in your technique, you don't easily lose your concentration when you {@action Cast a Spell|CRB}. If a reaction would disrupt your spellcasting action, attempt a DC {@flatDC 15} flat check. If you succeed, your action isn't disrupted.

feat.name: Striker's Scroll
entries: You can attach a scroll to your weapon to blend its spell into an attack, carefully folding it around a part of the weapon or pasting it to the weapon's surface. Attaching a scroll requires using the {@action Affix a Talisman||Affixing the Talisman} action (a 10-minute exploration activity with the manipulate trait found on page 565 of the Core Rulebook). You can have only one scroll affixed to a weapon at a time, and you can't have both a talisman and scroll attached.

You can {@action Cast a Spell||Cast the Spell} from the scroll after using {@action Striking Spell|PT:SoM} to store the scroll's spell in the attached weapon. You can't {@action Cast a Spell||Cast the Spell} in any other way while it's affixed, though you can use {@action Affix a Talisman||Affixing the Talisman} again to remove the scroll and use it as a normal—if a bit crumpled—scroll.

feat.name: Energize Strikes
feat.requirements: Your most recent action was to {@action Cast a Spell} with the acid, cold, electricity, fire, or sonic trait.
entries: You energize one weapon you're wielding with a spell. For 1 minute, your {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} with that weapon deal 1 additional damage per weapon damage die. The damage type matches the spell's trait. If the spell had more than one of the eligible traits, you choose the type when you Energize your {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes}.
You can instead put the spell energy into your body, conferring this additional damage on your unarmed attacks.

feat.name: Martial Caster
entries: You've strengthened your spellcasting to power you in combat. You gain two 1st-level spell slots, but you can prepare only certain spells in them: {@spell fleet step|CRB}, {@spell jump|CRB}, {@spell mage armor|CRB}, {@spell magic weapon|CRB}, and {@spell true strike|CRB}. Automatically add these spells to your spellbook.

When you can cast 4th-level magus spells, the extra slots increase to 2nd level and you add the spells {@spell resist energy|CRB}, {@spell spider climb|CRB}, and {@spell water breathing|CRB}. When you can cast 5th-level {@class magus|pt:som} spells, the extra slots increase to 3rd level and you add the spells {@spell feet to fins|CRB} and {@spell haste|CRB}. When you can cast 6th-level {@class magus|pt:som} spells, the extra slots increase to 4th level and you add the spells fly and {@spell freedom of movement|CRB}.

feat.name: Spell Countermeasures
entries: You can protect yourself against magic. You learn the spell countermeasures battle spell (page 11). Increase the number of Focus Points in your focus pool by 1.

feat.name: Capture Spell
feat.trigger: You succeed at your save against a foe's harmful spell targeting you, or a foe fails a spell attack roll against you from a harmful spell.
feat.requirements: You're benefiting from Spell Parry.
entries: When you resist a spell, you capture the magic in your weapon.

You store the spell in the parrying weapon as though you had used {@action Striking Spell|PT:SoM} (losing any spell currently stored in the weapon, as normal). This doesn't change any of the spell's effects based on the result of your saving throw; for instance, you'd still take half damage if you succeeded at a basic save.

feat.name: Standby Spell
entries: One spell is your favored combat technique, and you've practiced it enough that you no longer need to prepare it to cast it. Choose a spell in your spellbook that you could use with {@action Striking Spell|PT:SoM} and that has a level no higher than the highest-level {@class magus|pt:som} spell slot you have. You can {@action Cast a Spell||Cast this Spell} without having it prepared ahead of time by expending a spell slot of a sufficient level to cast the spell.
You can change this spell when you add new spells to your spellbook or by studying your spellbook for 1 hour per level of the newly chosen spell.

feat.name: Runic Impression
entries: You can temporarily replicate the effects of a property rune for your weapon or unarmed attacks. You learn the runic impression battle spell (page 11). Increase the number of Focus Points in your focus pool by 1.

feat.name: Spell Swipe
entries: You attack in an arc and can adapt your stored spell to harm everyone you hit. Make a melee {@action Strike|CRB} and compare the attack roll result to the AC of up to two foes, each of whom must be within your melee reach and adjacent to each other. Roll damage only once and apply it to each creature you hit. A Spell Swipe counts as two attacks for your multiple attack penalty.
If you had a spell stored in the weapon you attacked with (or in your body if you made an unarmed {@action Strike|CRB}), discharging it affects all foes you hit, not just the first target.
If you're using a weapon with the sweep trait, its modifier applies to all your Spell Swipe attacks, including spell attack rolls.

feat.name: Cascading Ray
feat.trigger: You discharge a stored spell that deals acid, cold, electricity, fire, force, negative, positive, or sonic damage.
entries: Magical energy overflows from your Striking Spell, spilling out to extend beyond the creature you struck. This overflowing energy creates a ray targeting a creature within 60 feet of the creature you damaged. Make a spell attack roll against this new target, applying your multiple attack penalty normally. On a hit, the creature takes the same damage the spell deals of one of the triggering types (double damage on a critical hit)

If the spell deals more than one eligible type of damage, you choose one of these types, and the ray deals only the amount of damage from that type. Unlike the spell discharged, your success with the Cascading Ray's spell attack roll isn't improved if your initial {@action Strike|CRB} was a critical hit. This ray has the attack trait, the school and tradition traits of the original spell, and the trait matching the damage type.

feat.name: Comet Spell
feat.trigger: You hit with a ranged {@action Strike} and discharge a stored spell that you had cast from a spell slot.
entries: You create a trail of magical energy that flows from your target back to you. Each creature in a line between you and the target, not including you or the target, takes force damage equal to the spell's level. If the triggering spell was of the evocation school, increase the damage by half the spell's level and change the damage type to one type dealt by the spell (your choice).

feat.name: Healer's Steel
feat.trigger: You gain temporary Hit Points from {@action Cast a Spell|CRB|Casting a Spell} altered by {@action Striking Spell|PT:SoM} using a spell slot.
entries: Rather than just protecting you, the spells you channel into your weapon actually {@spell heal|CRB} you. In addition to the temporary Hit Points you gain from sustaining steel, you can either regain Hit Points equal to twice the spell's level or end any {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent negative damage} you have. If the spell was of the necromancy school, you can both {@spell heal|CRB} yourself and end {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent negative damage}.

feat.name: Portal Slide
feat.trigger: You begin {@action Cast a Spell|CRB|Casting a Spell} altered by {@action Striking Spell|PT:SoM} from a spell slot.
entries: You can rapidly make a portal to step through as you store a spell. Rather than {@action Stride|CRB|Striding} or {@action Step|CRB|Stepping} as part of your {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} activity, you teleport up to half your Speed to a clear space you can see (this doesn't trigger reactions). If this would bring another creature with you, the spell is lost. If the spell you cast is of the conjuration or transmutation school, double the maximum distance you can teleport.

feat.name: Quickened Spellstrike
entries: You can muster intense focus to rapidly store a spell. You use Striking Spell. If your next action is to {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} to store in your body or a weapon, reduce the number of actions required to cast the spell by 1 (to a minimum of 1 action).

feat.name: Bespelled Persistence
entries: When you use {@feat Bespell Strikes|PT:G&G|Bespell Strike}, the weapon or unarmed attacks also deal {@dice 1d6} {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent damage}. This {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent damage} is of the same type Bespell {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} deals, except in the case of physical damage, which causes {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent bleed damage}.

feat.name: Magic Sense
entries: You have a literal sixth sense for ambient magic in your vicinity. You can sense the presence of magic auras as though you were always using a 1st-level {@spell detect magic|CRB} spell. This detects magic in your field of vision only. When you {@action Seek|CRB}, you gain the benefits of a 3rd-level {@spell detect magic|CRB} spell on things you see (in addition to the normal benefits of Seeking). You can turn this sense off and on with a free action at the start or the end of your turn.

feat.name: Overwhelming Spellstrike
entries: You pierce through your foe's resistance. {@action Strike|CRB} a foe. If your {@action Strike|CRB} discharges a stored spell that deals damage, the spell ignores an amount of the target's resistance to acid, cold, electricity, fire, or sonic damage equal to your level. This applies to all damage the spell deals, including {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent damage} and damage caused by an ongoing effect of the spell, such as the wall created by {@spell wall of fire|CRB}. A creature's immunities are unaffected.

feat.name: School Shroud
feat.requirements: Your most recent action was to cast a non‑cantrip spell.
entries: Your spell has a powerful aftereffect, briefly granting you the effects of a certain spell depending on the school of the spell you cast. This aftereffect lasts until the end of your next turn instead of its usual duration. Using School Shroud again ends any existing spell benefit you gained from School Shroud.

items: {@b Abjuration} {@spell stoneskin|CRB}
{@b Conjuration} {@spell blink|CRB}
{@b Divination} {@spell see invisibility|CRB}
{@b Enchantment} {@spell heroism|CRB}
{@b Evocation} {@spell fire shield|CRB}
{@b Necromancy} {@spell false life|CRB}
{@b Transmutation} {@spell fleet step|CRB}
{@b Illusion} {@spell invisibility|CRB} (ends after a {@condition hostile} action as normal)

feat.name: Hasted Assault
entries: You can speed yourself up to move and attack more swiftly.
You learn the {@spell hasted assault|PT:SoM} battle spell. Increase the number of Focus Points in your focus pool by 1.

feat.name: Preternatural Parry
feat.trigger: You're targeted by a {@action Strike} or a spell attack roll, or you're about to roll a saving throw against a spell effect.
feat.requirements: You're wielding only a single one-handed melee weapon and have your other hand or hands free.
entries: You snap your blade into place to ward off harm at the last second. You gain a +2 circumstance bonus to AC and saving throws against the triggering effect until the start of your next turn.

feat.name: Dispelling Spellstrike
feat.requirements: You have a spell stored in your weapon or body from Striking Spell.
entries: Your stored spell tries to force out the magic affecting a creature you hit. Make a {@action Strike|CRB} against a creature. If this {@action Strike|CRB} discharges the stored spell, you also attempt to counteract a single spell (of your choice) active on the target. The counteract level of Dispelling Spellstrike is equal to the level of the stored spell, and the counteract check modifier is the standard modifier for counteracting with a spell (your Intelligence modifier plus your spellcasting proficiency bonus, plus any bonuses or penalties that specifically apply to counteract checks).

feat.name: Effortless Concentration
feat.trigger: Your turn begins.
entries: You've trained your mind to maintain a spell with hardly a thought. You immediately gain the effects of the {@action Sustain a Spell|CRB} action, allowing you to extend the duration of one of your active {@class magus|pt:som} spells.

feat.name: Second Chance Strike
entries: When your target proves resilient to your magic, you can recall the magic back into your weapon or body to strike again. Whenever you discharge a spell from Striking Spell, if the target takes no effect (from a critical success on their save, a failed spell attack roll, immunity, etc), the spell isn't discharged and you can continue to attempt to discharge it with a later {@action Strike|CRB}. The spell must be discharged before the end of your next turn, as normal for Striking Spell.

feat.name: Versatile Spellstrike
entries: You can channel the entire realm of possibilities of your spellbook into an attack. Once during your daily preparations, you can use a spell slot to hold that infinite potential, rather than using it to prepare a spell. When you use {@action Striking Spell|PT:SoM} to alter a spell, instead of casting a prepared spell, you can expend this spell slot to cast any spell from your spellbook that's at least 2 levels lower than the slot's level. The spell acts in all ways as a spell of 2 levels lower. You don't have any particular spell prepared in that slot until you cast it.

feat.name: Supreme Spellstrike
entries: You've made it almost effortless to cast Striking Spells. You're permanently {@condition quickened}. You can use your extra action only to {@action Strike|CRB} with the unarmed attack or weapon storing a spell from Striking Spell.

feat.name: Whirlwind Spell
entries: You combine the might of a multitarget spell with a whirling flurry of attacks. You use Striking Spell, then {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} with a casting time of 1 or 2 actions, then make a melee {@action Strike|CRB} against each enemy within your reach. Each attack counts toward your multiple attack penalty but doesn't increase your penalty until you've made all your attacks. If you discharge the spell, you can affect each creature you hit with a {@action Strike|CRB}, up to the spell's normal maximum targets.

feat.name: Dual Studies
entries: You and your eidolon have each practiced some skills on your own, though not all your experiences translate with the shared link. Choose two different skills. Your eidolon becomes trained in one of those skills and you become trained in the other skill. At 7th level, you each become an expert in the chosen skills.

feat.name: Sensory Evolution
entries: Your eidolon evolves more acute senses. Your eidolon either gains {@ability low-light vision} and {@ability darkvision}, or gains {@ability scent} as an imprecise sense with a range of 30 feet.
special: You can select this feat twice, choosing the other option the second time.

feat.name: Synthesis
entries: You can manifest your eidolon using your own body as a vessel, taking on their form. When you {@action Manifest Eidolon|PT:SoM|Manifest your Eidolon} in this way, you become your eidolon, rather than them manifesting as a separate creature. While manifested in this way, you use your eidolon's statistics. Your eidolon can act, but you can't except to use {@action Manifest Eidolon|PT:SoM|Manifest an Eidolon} to unmanifest your eidolon. When you do, you remain behind in one square your eidolon occupied when you unmanifested it.

Since you can't act, you can't {@action Cast a Spell||Cast Spells}, activate or benefit from magic items that normally benefit you and not your eidolon, perform actions that have the tandem trait, or use other abilities that require you, and not the eidolon, to act. Your eidolon isn't limited by their distance to you, and you can't be separately targeted. When you reach 0 Hit Points, your eidolon unmanifests from your body, leaving your {@condition unconscious} body behind.

feat.name: Unfetter Eidolon
entries: You've learned magic that lets you temporarily allow your eidolon to travel far from your side. You learn the {@spell unfetter eidolon|PT:SoM} conduit spell. Increase the number of Focus Points in your focus pool by 1.

feat.name: Reinforce Eidolon
entries: You can increase your eidolon's defenses instead of their offense. You gain the {@spell reinforce eidolon|PT:SoM} conduit cantrip.

feat.name: Distracting Summon Spell
entries: You summon a creature exactly in the right spot to distract your foe from your eidolon, providing a perfect opportunity for your eidolon to attack. If the next action you take is to {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} to cast a 3-action summoning spell, when the spell is complete, your eidolon {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} a foe within reach of both the summoned creature and the eidolon as a free action. The foe is {@condition flat-footed} to the eidolon's {@action Strike|CRB}.

feat.name: Magical Evolution
entries: Your eidolon evolves to cast their own spells. Your eidolon gains the {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} activity and learns two cantrips of their tradition, which they cast as innate spells. Your eidolon uses your spell DC and spell attack modifier for these spells.

feat.name: Alacritous Evolution
entries: Your eidolon evolves to move more quickly on land. Your eidolon gains a +10-foot status bonus to their Speed.

feat.name: Amphibious Evolution
entries: Your eidolon adapts to life both on land and underwater. Your eidolon gains the amphibious trait, allowing them to breathe in water and in air and to avoid the normal –2 penalty for making bludgeoning and slashing unarmed {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} underwater. They gain a swim Speed equal to their land Speed or 25 feet, whichever is less. Alternatively, if your eidolon is normally aquatic, they gain a land Speed equal to their swim Speed or 25 feet, whichever is less.

feat.name: Tandem Move
entries: You and your eidolon move together with ease. You and your eidolon each use a single action to {@action Stride|CRB}. Either of you that has the corresponding movement type can {@action Burrow|CRB}, {@action Climb|CRB}, {@action Fly|CRB}, or {@action Swim|CRB} instead of {@action Stride||Striding}.

feat.name: Unarmed Evolution
entries: Your eidolon's unarmed attack evolves and gains a special trait. Choose one of your eidolon's starting melee unarmed attacks. The attack gains one of the following traits, which you choose when you gain this feat: {@trait disarm}, {@trait nonlethal}, {@trait shove}, {@trait trip}, or {@trait versatile}. If you choose {@trait versatile}, also choose whether it's B, P, or S.

feat.name: Climbing Evolution
entries: Your eidolon can climb with ease. Your eidolon gains a climb Speed equal to half their Speed or 25 feet, whichever is less.

feat.name: Hulking Evolution
entries: Your eidolon evolves, growing substantially in size. Your eidolon becomes Large, instead of their previous size. This doesn't change any other statistics for your eidolon.
Because of the special link you share, you can ride your eidolon without getting in each other's way.

entries.name: Riding Independent Creatures
entries: If a creature tries to ride your eidolon, both you and the riding creature each regain only 2 actions at the start of your turns each round, as both the eidolon and the riding creature interfere with one another's actions. If you have the {@feat Hulking Evolution|PT:SoM} feat, you're able to ride on your eidolon without this drawback.

feat.name: Ostentatious Arrival
entries: When you summon creatures or manifest your eidolon, there always seems to be an explosion. If the next action you take is to Manifest your Eidolon or to {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} to cast a 3-action summoning spell, the summoned eidolon or creature appears in an explosion of energy or other visually impressive display.

This deals {@scaledice 1d4|1-9|1d4} fire damage per spell level (or {@damage 1d4} damage per 2 levels you have when {@action Manifest Eidolon|PT:SoM|Manifesting your Eidolon}) to all creatures except you within a 10-foot emanation around the eidolon or summoned creature.

If the eidolon or summoned creature has the {@trait acid}, {@trait cold}, {@trait electricity}, {@trait sonic}, or {@trait water} trait, the damage is that type instead (or {@trait cold} damage in the case of the {@trait water} trait).

feat.name: Summoner Shield Evolution
entries: Your eidolon uses their manifested form to protect you when you're nearby. After your eidolon uses this action, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus to AC until the beginning of your next turn. This bonus applies only as long as you're in your eidolon's reach (in most cases, this means your eidolon is adjacent to you or in your space). This has no effect if you're not separately present, such as when using {@feat Synthesis|PT:SoM}.

feat.name: Flickering Evolution
entries: Your eidolon has gained the ability to make their ectoplasmic form briefly less substantial to avoid attacks while scouting ahead. Your eidolon can switch from their normal form to a less substantial flickering form or quasi-tangible ectoplasm. While in their flickering form, they gain resistance to all damage (except force and negative) equal to half your level. However, they can't use any of their {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} or actions requiring a fully physical form like {@action Grapple|CRB}, {@action Shove|CRB}, or {@action Trip|CRB}. Snapping back to their normal form is easier than diffusing themself into a flickering form. Your eidolon can switch back to their normal form as a single action, which also has the {@trait concentrate} trait.

feat.name: Greater Magical Evolution
entries: Your eidolon further evolves to gain more powerful magic.

Choose one 2nd-level spell and one 1st-level spell of your eidolon's tradition. Your eidolon can cast them each once per day as innate spells. At every even level after you take this feat, your eidolon can swap one of these innate spells for a new innate spell 2 or more levels lower than your highest-level spell slot.

feat.name: Ranged Evolution
entries: Your eidolon has developed a ranged attack. Your eidolon gains a ranged unarmed attack with a range increment of 30 feet that deals {@damage 1d6} damage and has the {@trait magical} trait. When you select this feat, choose a damage type from {@trait acid}, bludgeoning, {@trait cold}, {@trait electricity}, {@trait fire}, {@trait negative}, piercing, {@trait positive}, or slashing. If your eidolon is a celestial, fiend, or monitor with an alignment other than true neutral, you can instead choose a damage type in their alignment (for example, you could choose {@trait good} or {@trait lawful} if your lawful good angel eidolon gained this attack).

feat.name: Boost Summons
entries: Your ability to augment your eidolon extends to also benefit creatures you summon. When you cast {@spell boost eidolon|PT:SoM}, in addition to targeting your eidolon, it also targets any of your summoned creatures within 60 feet, granting them the same effects.

feat.name: Protective Bond
feat.trigger: You and your eidolon are both in the area of a damaging effect.
entries: You call upon the power of your bond to protect you both from harm. If you and your eidolon would take different amounts of damage from the area effect, you take the lower amount of damage instead of the greater amount of damage.

feat.name: Transpose
entries: With a flash, you switch places with your eidolon. You and your eidolon each teleport to the other's position.

feat.name: Conduit Focus
entries: Your focus recovers faster. If you've spent at least 2 Focus Points since the last time you {@action Refocus||Refocused}, you recover 2 Focus Points when you {@action Refocus|CRB} instead of 1.

feat.name: Summoner's Call
feat.trigger: You or your eidolon takes damage.
feat.requirements: Your eidolon is manifested and more than 5 feet away from you.
entries: In a moment of danger, you draw upon your link to quickly call your eidolon to your side. Your eidolon teleports from their previous location to an open space adjacent to you.

feat.name: Transmogrify
entries: You've learned how to transmogrify your eidolon in various ways to suit the circumstances of the day. Each day during your daily preparations, choose one {@filter evolution feat|feats||Class=Summoner|level=[0;6]} of 6th level or lower. Your eidolon gains that feat until your next daily preparations.

feat.name: Resilient Evolution
entries: Your eidolon grows a tougher hide, manifests armor, or otherwise becomes particularly resilient against physical attacks. They gain resistance to physical damage equal to their Constitution modifier.

feat.name: Spellguard Evolution
entries: Your eidolon evolves to protect themself from spells. They gain a +1 status bonus to all saving throws against magic.

feat.name: Towering Evolution
entries: Your eidolon further evolves, becoming more enormous and gaining a greater reach over the battlefield. Your eidolon becomes Huge, instead of Large, and the reach on all their attacks increases to 10 feet.

feat.name: Effortless Concentration
feat.trigger: Your turn begins.
entries: You maintain a spell with hardly a thought. You immediately gain the effects of the {@action Sustain a Spell|CRB} action, allowing you to extend the duration of one of your active spells.

feat.name: Winged Evolution
entries: Your eidolon grows wings, allowing them to fly. Your eidolon gains a fly Speed equal to their Speed.

feat.name: Conduit Wellspring
entries: The power between you and your eidolon replenishes your focus. If you've spent at least 3 Focus Points since the last time you {@action Refocus||Refocused}, you recover 3 Focus Points when you {@action Refocus|CRB} instead of 1.

feat.name: True Transmogrification
entries: You can make incredibly expansive adjustments to your eidolon to prepare for virtually any situation you might find yourself in. Each day during your daily preparations, when you apply your evolution feat from {@feat Transmogrify|PT:SoM}, you can also swap out any number of other evolution feats you have, each for a different evolution feat of the same level or lower. These swaps last until your next daily preparations.

feat.name: Twin Eidolon
entries: You can transform yourself to match your eidolon. When you Manifest your Eidolon, in addition to their normal manifestation, you can call upon their powers to transform yourself into an exact duplicate of your eidolon until the eidolon becomes unmanifested. You can't use this if you Manifest your Eidolon in an unusual way, such as with the {@feat Synthesis|PT:SoM} feat. While a duplicate of your eidolon, you use your eidolon's statistics other than your mental ability modifiers, including their evolutions. You can't cast spells (unless they're spells your eidolon could cast), activate or benefit from magic items that normally benefit you and not your eidolon, or use other actions your eidolon can't normally perform. Any spells you cast with a limited number of uses count against your eidolon's uses. You can Manifest your Eidolon again to end this effect and return to your normal form.

feat.name: Eidolon's Avatar
feat.prerequisites: eidolon from a plane other than the Material Plane
entries: Your complete connection to your eidolon and your eidolon's growth alongside you into a being of great power grant you special privileges within another plane. Once per day, you can cast {@spell plane shift|CRB} as an innate spell of your eidolon's tradition, but only to travel to the plane of origin of your eidolon. When you cast it this way, its casting time is 1 minute, your link to your eidolon is a sufficient tuning fork for this spell, and you appear exactly where you want to be. If you're on your eidolon's home plane due to this spell, you can return to the point you left when you cast it by spending a single action, which has the {@trait concentrate} trait and the trait matching your eidolon's tradition.

If you conduct the commune ritual to contact entities from your eidolon's plane that are {@condition friendly} to your eidolon, you don't have to pay any cost and you automatically get a critical success.

feat.name: Eternal Boost
entries: Your link with your eidolon is so intense that you can always boost your eidolon. You're permanently {@condition quickened}; you can use your extra action only to cast {@spell boost eidolon|PT:SoM} or {@spell reinforce eidolon|PT:SoM}. While in exploration mode, you can declare that you're also continually casting {@spell boost eidolon|PT:SoM} or {@spell reinforce eidolon|PT:SoM} even while using a different {@trait exploration} activity. If you do, even before your first turn in a combat encounter, that cantrip is active as if you had cast it on your previous turn.

feat.name: Cover Fire
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm or crossbow, and a foe you can see within the weapon's maximum range has cover.
entries: You lay down suppressive fire to protect your allies and pin down your opponents. You make a firearm or crossbow {@action Strike|CRB} targeting the foe, who must decide whether to duck behind cover (no action required) or not before you roll your attack roll. If the target ducks, it Takes Cover against your attack, gaining a +4 circumstance bonus to AC from greater cover, but also takes a –2 circumstance penalty to ranged attacks until the end of its next turn. This greater cover applies only against your {@action Strike|CRB}, not to future attacks. If the target chooses not to duck, the {@action Strike|CRB} functions normally.

feat.name: Firearm Ace
entries: You have a practiced understanding of firearms' workings, their mechanisms, and the best way to utilize them. When you're wielding a firearm and {@action Interact|CRB} to reload it, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus to the damage roll on your next {@action Strike|CRB} with that firearm. If the firearm is a simple firearm, increase the damage die size for that attack by one step. You must make the attack before the end of your turn or these benefits are lost.

feat.name: Hit The Dirt!
feat.trigger: A creature you can see attempts a ranged {@action Strike} against you.
entries: You fling yourself out of {@spell harm|CRB}'s way, perhaps through quick thinking or pure instinct. You {@action Leap|CRB} to avoid {@spell harm|CRB}, gaining a +2 circumstance bonus to AC against the triggering attack.
Regardless of whether or not the triggering attack hits, you land {@condition prone} after completing your {@action Leap|CRB}.

feat.name: Sword And Pistol
entries: You're experienced in combining melee attacks with shots from a firearm or crossbow, quickly adapting your range and style to the current situation. When you make a successful ranged {@action Strike|CRB} against an opponent within your melee reach using a firearm or crossbow, that opponent becomes {@condition flat-footed} against your next melee attack. When you successfully {@action Strike|CRB} an opponent with a melee weapon, the next ranged {@action Strike|CRB} you make against that opponent doesn't trigger reactions that would trigger only on a ranged attack but not a melee attack, such as {@action Attack of Opportunity|CRB}.
The benefit on your next {@action Strike|CRB} from either use of Sword and Pistol is lost if not used by the end of your next turn.

feat.name: Assisting Shot
entries: With a quick shot, you interfere with a foe during combat.

Make a {@action Strike|CRB} with a firearm or crossbow. If the {@action Strike|CRB} hits, the next creature other than you to attack the same target before the start of your next turn gains a +1 circumstance bonus to their roll, or a +2 circumstance bonus if your {@action Strike|CRB} was a critical hit.

feat.name: Blast Lock
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm.
entries: Sometimes taking the shortest distance between two points involves removing an obstacle or two. You shoot the required firearm at a lock within 10 feet. Make your attack roll against the DC required to {@action Pick a Lock|CRB|Pick the Lock}.

entries.Critical Success: You open the lock, or you achieve two successes toward opening a complex lock.
entries.Success: You open the lock, or you achieve one success toward opening a complex lock.
entries.Failure: You fail to open the lock, and your shot makes it harder to open. Future attempts to {@action Pick a Lock|CRB|Pick the Lock} take a –2 circumstance penalty.
entries.Critical Failure: You fail to open the lock, and your shot makes it much harder to open. Future attempts to {@action Pick a Lock|CRB|Pick the Lock} take a–4 circumstance penalty.

feat.name: Pistol Twirl
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded, one-handed ranged weapon.
entries: Your quick gestures and performative flair distract an opponent, leaving them vulnerable to your attack. You {@action Feint|CRB} against an opponent within the required weapon's first range increment, rather than an opponent within melee reach. On a success or critical success, the foe is {@condition flat-footed} against your melee and ranged attacks, rather than only your melee attacks. On a critical failure, you're {@condition flat-footed} against both the target's melee and ranged attacks, rather than only its melee attacks.

feat.name: Quick Draw
entries: You draw your weapon and attack with the same motion. You {@action Interact|CRB} to draw a weapon, then {@action Strike|CRB} with that weapon.

feat.name: Risky Reload
feat.requirements: You're wielding a firearm.
entries: You've practiced a technique for rapidly reloading your firearm, but it's a dangerous gamble with your firearm's functionality.
{@action Interact|CRB} to reload a firearm, then make a {@action Strike|CRB} with that firearm. If the {@action Strike|CRB} fails, the firearm misfires.

feat.name: Warning Shot
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm.
entries: Who needs words when the roar of a gun is so much more succinct? You attempt to {@action Demoralize|CRB} a foe by firing your weapon into the air, using the firearm's maximum range rather than the usual range of 30 feet. This check doesn't take the–4 circumstance penalty if the target doesn't share a language with you.

feat.name: Alchemical Shot
feat.requirements: You have an alchemical bomb worn or in one hand, and are wielding a loaded firearm.
entries: You've practiced a technique for mixing alchemical bombs with your loaded shot. You {@action Interact|CRB} to retrieve the bomb (if it's not already in your hand) and pour it onto your ammunition, consuming the bomb. Then {@action Strike|CRB} with your weapon. The {@action Strike|CRB} deals damage of the same type as the bomb (for instance, fire damage for {@class alchemist|CRB}'s fire), and it deals an additional {@dice 1d6} {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent damage} of the same type as the bomb. If the {@action Strike|CRB} fails, you take {@dice 1d6} damage of the same type as the bomb you used, and the firearm misfires.
The {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent damage} increases to {@dice 2d6} if the bomb is level 11 or higher, or {@dice 3d6} if it's level 17 or higher.

feat.name: Black Powder Boost
feat.trigger: You Leap.
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm.
entries: While dashing into position, you fire your weapon behind you to speed yourself along. You fire your weapon beneath or behind you, adding 10 feet to either the horizontal or vertical distance you travel. If your {@action Leap|CRB} required a roll (such as a {@action High Jump|CRB} or {@action Long Jump|CRB}), you can use this reaction after determining the result.

feat.name: Running Reload
entries: You can reload your weapon on the move. You {@action Stride|CRB}, {@action Step|CRB}, or {@action Sneak|CRB}, then {@action Interact|CRB} to reload.

feat.name: Cauterize
feat.requirements: You're wielding a firearm that you've fired this turn, and you or an adjacent ally are taking persistent bleed damage.
entries: You press your gun's heated barrel to your wounds or those of an ally, instantly granting a flat check to end the bleed with a lower DC for particularly {@condition persistent damage||effective assistance}.

feat.name: Pistolero's Challenge
entries: With a stern callout, a carefully chosen barb, or some other challenging declaration, you demand your foe's attention in a duel. Choose an opponent within 30 feet who you can perceive and can hear you, and make your choice of a {@skill Deception} or {@skill Intimidation} check. No matter the result of the check, the foe is temporarily immune to your Pistolero's Challenge until noon the next day. You can have only one challenge in effect at a time; challenging a new opponent ends this effect on any current target. Otherwise, the effect lasts until one of you is defeated or flees or the encounter ends.

entries.Success: Both you and the opponent gain a +2 status bonus to damage rolls with {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} made against each other. If you're a master in the skill you used for the check, the status bonus to damage rolls increases to +3, and if you're legendary, it increases to +4.
entries.Critical Failure: You become {@condition frightened} 1 and can't use this ability again for 1 minute.

feat.name: Reloading Strike
feat.requirements: You're wielding a firearm or crossbow and your other hand either wields a one-handed melee weapon or is empty.
entries: You attack and then reload your gun in one fluid movement.
{@action Strike|CRB} an opponent within reach with your melee weapon or an unarmed attack, and then {@action Interact|CRB} to reload. You don't need a free hand to reload in this way.

feat.name: Scatter Blast
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm that has the scatter trait.
entries: You pack your weapon with additional shot and powder, creating a risky but devastating arc of destruction. Make a ranged {@action Strike|CRB} with the required weapon. The range of your weapon increases from 15 feet to 30 feet, or 30 feet to 60 feet.
If the weapon's range is already 60 feet or greater, this ability has no effect. The {@action Strike|CRB} gains the following failure conditions.

entries.Critical Failure: The firearm explodes, becoming {@condition broken}, and deals its normal weapon damage (including fundamental and property runes) to all creatures in a 20-foot burst with a basic Reflex save against your class DC.

feat.name: Shattering Shot
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm or crossbow and have a worn or wielded bomb that has the splash trait.
entries: You fling a bomb into the air and then shoot it, causing a damaging rain over a wide area. If necessary, you {@action Interact|CRB} to draw the bomb and re-grip your weapon. You throw your bomb to the corner of a square within your firearm's first range increment and shoot it with your firearm. All creatures in a 15-foot burst of the bomb take splash damage equal to the amount of precision damage One Shot, One Kill deals. The damage type is the same as the bomb would deal.

feat.name: Grit And Tenacity
feat.trigger: You fail a Fortitude or Will save.
entries: You call upon deep reserves of toughness and mental fortitude to power through an otherwise debilitating effect. Reroll the triggering save with a +2 circumstance bonus.

feat.name: Paired Shots
feat.requirements: You're wielding two loaded one-handed crossbows or firearms.
entries: Your shots strike their target almost simultaneously. Make two {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes}, one with each of your two ranged weapons and each using your current multiple attack penalty. Both {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} must have the same target.
If both attacks hit, combine their damage and then add any applicable effects from both weapons. You add any precision damage only once to the attack of your choice.
Combine the damage from both {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} and apply resistances and weaknesses only once. This counts as two attacks when calculating your multiple attack penalty.

feat.name: Return Fire
entries: You're quick enough to line up a shot even while diving to the ground. When you use your Hit the Dirt! reaction, at any point during your {@action Leap|CRB}, you can also make a ranged {@action Strike|CRB} with a loaded firearm or crossbow against the creature whose attack triggered the reaction.

feat.name: Shooter's Aim
entries: You take an extra moment to carefully align your aim and breathing. Make a ranged weapon {@action Strike|CRB}. You gain a +2 circumstance bonus to this {@action Strike|CRB}'s attack roll and ignore the target's concealment. If you're using a firearm with the {@trait unsteady|PT:G&G} trait, you don't take the normal circumstance penalty for firing without using a {@item tripod|PT:G&G} or {@action Interact|CRB} action to aim on this {@action Strike|CRB}.

feat.name: Smoke Curtain
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm.
entries: You load an extra dose of black powder into your shot, causing it to belch out a roiling cloud of smoke. Make a {@action Strike|CRB} with your firearm to create a cloud of smoke in a 20-foot burst centered on your location. Creatures are {@condition concealed} while within the smoke, and creatures outside the area are {@condition concealed} to creatures within the smoke. The smoke dissipates in 1 round. The {@action Strike|CRB} gains the following critical failure effect.

entries.Critical Failure: The firearm misfires (see sidebar on page 4).

feat.name: Called Shot
entries: You target a specific part of your foe's body, damaging the chosen limb or body part in a way that hinders your foe's ability to move, fight, or think. Declare a portion of your foe's anatomy to target and make a ranged weapon {@action Strike|CRB}. If you hit and deal damage, apply one of the following effects to the target until the end of your next turn, based on the body part you targeted.

items: {@bold Arms} (or another limb used for attacks, such as a tentacle) The target is {@condition enfeebled} 2. On a critical hit, it's also {@condition enfeebled} 1 for 1 minute.
{@bold Head} The target is {@condition stupefied} 2. On a critical hit, it's also {@condition stupefied} 1 for 1 minute.
{@bold Legs} (or tail on a legless creature) The target takes a–10-foot status penalty to its Speeds. On a critical hit, it also takes–5-foot penalty to its Speeds for 1 minute.

{@bold Wings} If the target is flying using its wings, it immediately falls 20 feet, or 40 feet on a critical hit. The fall is gradual enough that if it causes the target to hit the ground, the target takes no damage from the fall.

feat.name: Deflecting Shot
feat.trigger: An ally within the first range increment of your firearm or crossbow is hit by an attack, and you can see the attacker.
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm or crossbow.
entries: When your weapon is loaded, you're always ready to fire it to deflect an attack against your ally. The ally gains a +2 circumstance bonus to their AC against the triggering attack.

You use this reaction after the result of the attack roll is revealed, so you know whether the +2 will make a sufficient difference (for example, whether it will turn a success into a failure or a critical success into a success).

feat.name: Redirecting Shot
feat.trigger: An ally misses with a ranged attack that uses a {@trait thrown} weapon or ammunition.
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm or crossbow.
entries: Seeing your ally's attack about to go astray, you fire your weapon to right its course. Make an attack roll with your firearm or crossbow against the target of the triggering attack, ignoring any bonus the target would gain against you from lesser or standard cover. Your ally's attack uses your attack roll instead of their attack roll.

feat.name: Trick Shot
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm.
entries: You shoot not at your foe, but at an object nearby. Make a {@action Strike|CRB} with your firearm against an AC of 25, or a different AC at the GM's discretion. Instead of hitting your foe, your attack hits an object behind or to the side of your target, creating one of the following effects. The GM might determine a particular effect isn't a valid option, such as using explosive barrel when there's no such object on the battlefield. The GM determines such cases and should inform you before you spend the actions for a Trick Shot.

items: {@bold Dislodge Object} Your attack knocks an unattended object of no more than 2 Bulk out of position, moving it up to 10 feet in a direction of your choice. For example, the weapon could knock a {@class wizard|CRB}'s crystal ball off a table.

{@bold Explosive Barrel} Your attack strikes a barrel of expensive rum, a vial of volatile alchemical fluids, an erupting demonic pustule, or some other explosive object. The object explodes in a 20-foot burst and all creatures in the area take {@dice 6d6} damage with a basic Reflex save against your class DC. The damage type is chosen by the GM based on the exploding object. Increase the damage by {@dice 1d6} for every 2 levels you have above 10th

feat.name: Glancing Shot
entries: Even when your shots don't land cleanly, they still land close enough to inflict some damage. Make a ranged {@action Strike|CRB}. It gains the following failure effect.

entries.Failure: Your attack deals any damage it would have dealt on a hit, excluding all damage dice (this removes damage dice from weapons, runes, spells, and special abilities, in addition to weapon damage dice).

feat.name: Incredible Ricochet
entries: After your first shot singles out your opponent's position, you direct another shot that ricochets around obstacles and strikes unerringly. Make a ranged weapon {@action Strike|CRB} against a creature you previously attacked this turn. You ignore the target's {@condition concealed} condition and all cover.

feat.name: Penetrating Fire
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm or crossbow.
